abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Zambia Second Economic and Social
            Adjustment Credit (ESAC II). The objective of the project
            was to support Zambia's economic reform program and to
            aid in the reduction of poverty by promoting broad-based,
            private sector-led growth and improving the delivery of
            vital social services. Bank's performance was
            satisfactory. Borrower's performance was satisfactory.
            The key lessons learned were as follows: (i) adjustment for
            low income countries, especially those facing external
            shocks like Zambia, is a long and arduous process; (ii)
            future operations should aim at fewer, and probably more
            critical, conditions, particularly in an election period;
            (iii) it may be important in adjustment operations such as
            ESAC II to identify at the design stage the likely
            implementation bottlenecks and to provide, for instance
            through a Technical Assistance loan, the resources needed to
            help enhance implementation capacity of the government; (iv)
            The nature of Non Govermental Organizations (NGOs) as a
            heterogeneous group and the complexity of the government and
            NGO relationship make it difficult for adjustment lending to
            be an effective instrument for dealing with government and
            NGO issues; and (v) Future International Development
            Association (IDA) operations will have to give more
            attention to issues of budgetary planning and management if
            expenditures for social programs are to be protected.
